section.title: Setting the Page Size
section.p: If you do not set the size, uses portrait US-LETTER with margins of 1in.
You can also specify the page orientation using the portrait or landscape keywords.
You can use the @page rule multiple times and the properties will merge as in ordinary CSS element styling rules.

section.title: Using Page Selectors to Style the Blank, Left, Right, First, and Last Pages
section.p: There are cases where you need to have different page settings depending on the position of the page in the printed material.
The :first and :last selectors are used to style the first and last page from a sequence of pages.
The :blank selector is used to style the blank pages that appear as a result of forced page breaks.

section.title: Using Named Pages
section.p: In the examples above, the default page settings were changed.

Now suppose that you need to put a particular table elements on a landscape page. The example below defines a named page table-landscape-page that switches the orientation to landscape. Then, to maximize the space available to the table, the margin is reduced for this page. Also, the A4 size defined by the default @page rule is inherited by the named page.

Also, allows you to break a sequence of elements that have the same page in different page groups. A simple example is a set of chapter elements where you need to apply specific formatting for the first page from each chapter.

But this is not enough. According to the W3C specification, all chapters that have the same page will be merged in a single page group (sequence), and the :first selector will thus apply only on the first page from the first chapter. Therefore, you need to use the -oxy-page-group property on each of the chapter elements.
The accepted values for the -oxy-page-group property are:

ul.li: start - Forces the creation of a new page group (sequence) even if the page before the element has the same name. The W3C specification algorithm () would merge the current element with the opened page sequence.
auto - Use the W3C algorithm normally.
